awd_titl_txt: Investigate the Molecular Basis of Crosstalk between the Circadian Clock and Innate Immunity in Arabidopsis
awd_abstract_narration:
Pathogen-induced diseases lead to tremendous economic loss worldwide. The use of chemicals and pesticides to control plant diseases risks collateral damage to the environment and human health. Therefore it is important to understand how plants fight against pathogens and subsequently to use such information to control plant resistance to devastating diseases. Upon frequent challenges imposed by pathogens, plants activate different defense responses at different times of a day, a process recently shown to be controlled by the endogenous biological timekeeper called the circadian clock. The circadian clock integrates temporal information with environmental stimuli (such as pathogen infections) to regulate many biological processes, including plant defense responses. The investigators previously demonstrated that changes in plant defense status could affect clock activity. However how defense responses and clock activity are co-regulated in plants remains unclear. This project seeks insights into the mechanisms that coordinate the circadian clock with defense responses. Importantly, this project provides excellent training opportunities to students, especially women, underrepresented minority students and K-12 science teachers. Students and postdocs involved in this project will be broadly trained in biology and bioinformatics so as to be better prepared for future careers in science. Research experiences will also be provided to K-12 teachers from low performing public schools in the Baltimore area. Science teachers are the key to making connections between knowledge acquired in the classroom and research conducted in the laboratory. The research experience that will be provided will enable them to design a more effective science curriculum for their classes.

The goal of this collaborative project is to understand the interplay between the controls of innate immunity and the circadian clock in Arabidopsis. Specifically the project seeks to identify and characterize genes that control defense and/or clock activities and elucidate how these genes act together to orchestrate disease resistance, growth, and development of Arabidopsis. To address this goal, a team of experts in plant defense, circadian clock, and systems biology fields will employ traditional molecular, genetic and biochemical approaches as well as computational modeling to implement the proposed activities. Information obtained from this study will enhance our fundamental knowledge about disease resistance, growth and development of plants. Genes identified from this study can be used as molecular tools to genetically manipulate disease resistance traits in economically important crop plants. Such plants will reduce our dependency on chemicals and pesticides, thus protecting the environment and human health and supporting sustainable agriculture.

por.por_cntn:
Pathogen-induced diseases cause tremendous economic loss worldwide. The use of chemicals and pesticides to control plant diseases risks collateral damage to the environment and human health. Therefore, it is important to understand how plants fight against pathogens and subsequently to use such information to improve plant resistance to devastating diseases. Upon pathogen challenges, plants activate different defense responses at different times of a day, a process recently shown to be controlled by the endogenous biological timekeeper called the circadian clock. The circadian clock integrates temporal information with environmental stimuli (such as pathogen infections) to regulate many biological processes, including development and defense responses. Defense is energetically costly process and comes at the expense of reduced growth, so knowing when to activate defense and when to grow is critical for the health of plants. This project aims to provide insights into the mechanisms that coordinate the circadian clock with defense responses. To achieve this goal, a team of experts in plant defense, the circadian clock, and systems biology fields employed traditional molecular, genetic and biochemical approaches as well as computational modeling to elucidate the clock-defense signaling networks. They identified and characterized key clock genes for their roles in pathogen defense and revealed how defense activation by pathogens reciprocally regulates the host circadian clock. 

Information obtained from this study has enhanced our fundamental knowledge about disease resistance, growth, and development of plants. Genes identified from this study can be used as potential molecular tools to genetically manipulate disease resistance traits in economically important crop plants, ultimately enhancing crop productivity. Such plants will reduce our dependency on chemicals and pesticides, thus protecting the environment and human health and supporting sustainable agriculture. In addition, innate immunity of plants shares certain conserved features with that of animals. Although the core clock components of plants differ largely from those of other organisms, the basic principles of the clock function are consistent. Therefore, knowledge obtained from plants regarding the role of the circadian clock in plant-pathogen interactions should be useful to our understanding of similar questions related to other host-pathosystems.  

This project provided research training opportunities to students at different academic levels. A summer internship program, the Research Training for Future Science Teachers and High School Students program, was established to provide research experience to UMBC undergraduate students who aspired to become future K-12 science teachers and high school students of underrepresented groups from Baltimore City schools. An in-classroom teaching module was developed for a laboratory course to provide hands-on research experience to undergraduate students in a large-classroom setting. The PI has also extended education outreach to the general public by hosting public events (Plants Day Celebration) and disseminating scientific knowledge through online articles.
